oracle_info.speaker: Lynne Neagle AM
oracle_info.content: Welcome to the Children, Young People and Education Committee.

oracle_info.speaker: Lynne Neagle AM
oracle_info.content: Item 2, then, this morning is a scrutiny session with a focus on higher and further education.

oracle_info.speaker: Lynne Neagle AM
oracle_info.content: If you're okay with it, we'll go straight into questions.

oracle_info.speaker: Suzy Davies AM
oracle_info.content: If we can just start with teacher training and teacher training for secondary school teachers in particular, obviously there's been what looks like a trend in recent years in filling the places for secondary school training.

oracle_info.speaker: Suzy Davies AM
oracle_info.content: Presumably, some research has been done about why people don't want to become teachers so that the answers you come up with are appropriate answers.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: That's why we set up the advisory group under the chairmanship of Professor John Gardner—it's to understand what the issues are exactly that are preventing people or putting people off.

oracle_info.speaker: Hefin David AM
oracle_info.content: The decision by the Education Workforce Council not to accredit the University of South Wales with the ability to deliver teacher training—what are your views and concerns about that?

oracle_info.speaker: Lynne Neagle AM
oracle_info.content: We're going to move on now to talk about reform and reconfiguration of the post-16 education sector.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: The universities are required, under the Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015, to produce fee and access statements, and the £104 million that they have to take off their fees to be able to promote this work—those fee and access plans have to be signed off by the Higher Education Funding Council for Wales as being robust and truly promoting equality of opportunity.

oracle_info.speaker: Hefin David AM
oracle_info.content: Cabinet Secretary, are you in favour of more university mergers?

oracle_info.speaker: Lynne Neagle AM
oracle_info.content: We're going to move on now to look at the parity of esteem between academic and vocational post-16 education.

oracle_info.speaker: Eluned Morgan AM
oracle_info.content: Well, what we are doing is we're putting money into areas where we know there are skills shortages.

oracle_info.speaker: Llyr Gruffydd AM
oracle_info.content: I'd like to ask about the regional skills partnership—partnerships, I should say—because they are having a direct influence now on courses and provision in FE, and with degree apprenticeships in universities as well.

oracle_info.speaker: Dawn Bowden AM
oracle_info.content: I wanted to ask you about the pay dispute, and I know that you're not the employer, because I know that's going to be the first answer—

oracle_info.speaker: Hefin David AM
oracle_info.content: You will have had, Cabinet Secretary, a letter from Professor Colin Riordan on 26 September regarding essay mills, in which he refers to the other letter that was sent by him and 39 vice-chancellors regarding essay mills and the fact that it's legalised cheating.

oracle_info.speaker: Hefin David AM
oracle_info.content: Can you just give me your opinions on that, please?

specific_query_list.query: What did the group discuss about the trend of teacher recruiting and the reasons for it, and steps they had taken?

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: I think, for this year's intake, although we're in touch with our providers, we're not in a position to be able to give figures for this year's intake for a couple of months.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: But what we have seen over recent years is that we are only recruiting to about 65 per cent of those targets.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: We have looked at financial incentives.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: It's not the whole answer, I think, to these issues, but it's part of a mixture of things that we need to do.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: I think what you will find is that this isn't a uniquely Welsh issue.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: I think they are suffering quite acute problems across the border, which proves to me that money isn't necessarily the entire answer, because, despite higher financial incentives to join ITE courses, they're not able to do that in England either.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: So, that proves to me—what the research does show—that it's not money alone that will get people onto these courses.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: So, what we're doing is first of all making sure that our ITE provision is world class, so that, actually, Welsh centres are the place to go to train to be a teacher.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: We're also embarking on our first ever national ITE recruitment marketing exercise.

oracle_info.speaker: Llyr Gruffydd AM
oracle_info.content: So, it's a huge turnaround that we're looking for, and I'm not getting the feeling that the level of ambition and the answers that you're giving here this morning reflect the level of action that's needed, really.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: So, there are statistics and there are statistics.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: Depending on which ones you look at, it's quite a complex picture.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: We understand and we know and acknowledge that there is more work to be done.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: As I said, we're not sitting back and hoping that something miraculous will change things.

specific_query_list.query: What did Kirsty Williams say about the trend of teacher recruiting, the reasons for it, and the steps they had taken?

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: I think, for this year's intake, although we're in touch with our providers, we're not in a position to be able to give figures for this year's intake for a couple of months.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: But what we have seen over recent years is that we are only recruiting to about 65 per cent of those targets.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: So, there is still a job of work to do to understand and to respond to those needs.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: So, what we're doing is first of all making sure that our ITE provision is world class, so that, actually, Welsh centres are the place to go to train to be a teacher.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: You'll be aware that we've recently been through an accreditation process for new ITE provision that will start in the next academic year.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: We have looked at financial incentives.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: We're also embarking on our first ever national ITE recruitment marketing exercise.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: I think what you will find is that this isn't a uniquely Welsh issue.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: I think they are suffering quite acute problems across the border, which proves to me that money isn't necessarily the entire answer, because, despite higher financial incentives to join ITE courses, they're not able to do that in England either.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: So, that proves to me—what the research does show—that it's not money alone that will get people onto these courses.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: There's high demand for those places, so much so that we've increased those places to 90 last year and 90 again this year, which says to me that—there's definitely a place for the traditional, 'Take a year off, do a postgraduate certificate in education in a university for a year'—actually, that type of course suits some students but it might be preventing other people from pursuing a qualification in teaching, which is why, of course, from next year, we will have our unique part-time PGCE route into qualification.

oracle_info.speaker: Suzy Davies AM
oracle_info.content: Well, that's what I was after finding out, and, actually, what you've just said about the part-time PGCE is pretty interesting as well, because if you can bring your outside world experience into teaching, that's got to help, hasn't it?

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: I think that is really, really important—that we have a diversity in our teaching workforce.

specific_query_list.query: How did Kirsty Williams respond to the doubt that their action was not enough?

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: Well, first of all, as I tried to illustrate to Suzy, the figures on their own tell one story, but there are additional people in the system with an ability to speak Welsh and to be able to use—

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: And if we look at qualifiers of ITE courses in Wales by degree type, actually, we see a different trend—we see numbers going up.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: So, there are statistics and there are statistics.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: Depending on which ones you look at, it's quite a complex picture.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: We understand and we know and acknowledge that there is more work to be done.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: That's why we have got the evaluation of provision in ITE and that's why we'll be taking that ambition forward.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: As I said, we're not sitting back and hoping that something miraculous will change things.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: We are pulling levers and putting in place plans to improve that situation.

specific_query_list.query: Summarize their discussion on the decision of not accrediting the University of South Wales with the ability to deliver teacher training.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: The process is independent of Government, and it would not be appropriate for me to comment on that, especially as I understand that there is an appeals process that may be being undertaken.

oracle_info.speaker: Hefin David AM
oracle_info.content: I fully understand that and the need for distance for the EWC, but there'll be an impact on students and staff.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: Clearly, there will be a responsibility upon the University of South Wales to ensure that those students already in the system are able to complete their studies and their course, with the appropriate level of support and tuition to enable them to achieve their career aspirations and to graduate from that programme.

oracle_info.speaker: Hefin David AM
oracle_info.content: And what about the uncertainty for staff, or would you say that's an issue for the university itself?

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: That's not a matter for me; that is a matter for the institution that is an autonomous body.

oracle_info.speaker: Suzy Davies AM
oracle_info.content: It's not directly about USW; it's about the geographic spread of provision.

specific_query_list.query: What was Kirsty Williams' opinion of the decision of not accrediting the University of South Wales with the ability to deliver teacher training?

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: The process is independent of Government, and it would not be appropriate for me to comment on that, especially as I understand that there is an appeals process that may be being undertaken.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: What I would say is that from the very outset of our ITE reforms we have made it very clear that I expect very high standards in our ITE system, but the process is independent of this Government.

oracle_info.speaker: Hefin David AM
oracle_info.content: I fully understand that and the need for distance for the EWC, but there'll be an impact on students and staff.

oracle_info.speaker: Hefin David AM
oracle_info.content: Would you have concerns about that issue?

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: Clearly, there will be a responsibility upon the University of South Wales to ensure that those students already in the system are able to complete their studies and their course, with the appropriate level of support and tuition to enable them to achieve their career aspirations and to graduate from that programme.

specific_query_list.query: Summarize Kirsty Williams' opinion on the current geographic spread of provision when discussing the decision of not accrediting the University of South Wales with the ability to deliver teacher training.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: Currently, with our current providers, there is a significant geographical spread.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: We do think that, for some students, accessibility is an issue, and of course that's why we are responding with our part-time PGCE route, which actually will be location neutral, because you will be able to study that as a distance learner, and so you will be able to remain in your community and undertake that course.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: So, if geographical disadvantage is stopping somebody from pursuing a career aspiration to qualify as a teacher, our new part-time PGCE, as I said, will allow them to do that.

specific_query_list.query: Summarize their discussions on university mergers.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: I wouldn't use the word 'agnostic', but what I'm in favour of is a healthy, strong and sustainable HE sector.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: We're not pursuing or urging a policy of mergers, but, if individual institutions feel that is of benefit to them and their students, obviously, we would have an interest in that and making sure that they were robust plans, but that's a matter for individual institutions.

oracle_info.speaker: Hefin David AM
oracle_info.content: That's a little bit of a contrast with your predecessors, then.

oracle_info.speaker: Hefin David AM
oracle_info.content: The reason I say it is because I was kind of on the inside when Cardiff Metropolitan University was under pressure from the then Minister to merge with the University of Glamorgan and Newport.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: Well, look, as it's turned out, we have a strong institution in Cardiff Met, and I think, rather than looking at the past, we need to look at the future.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: But, of course, there was some reconfiguration and we need to understand any lessons that arose out of reconfiguration, and HEFCW are currently doing some work, actually, to look at reconfiguration, the experience of reconfiguration that did happen, and were benefits realised and what are the lessons that can be learned from that process.

specific_query_list.query: How did Kirsty Williams respond to university mergers?

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: I wouldn't use the word 'agnostic', but what I'm in favour of is a healthy, strong and sustainable HE sector.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: If individual institutions wish to collaborate or, indeed, go further to a formal merger then, obviously, that is a matter for them.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: We're not pursuing or urging a policy of mergers, but, if individual institutions feel that is of benefit to them and their students, obviously, we would have an interest in that and making sure that they were robust plans, but that's a matter for individual institutions.

specific_query_list.query: Did Kirsty Williams feel there had been any disadvantages to Cardiff Met because that merger did not go ahead?

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: I, personally, am not aware of any disadvantage to Cardiff Met, but I would recognise—I would absolutely recognise—for staff and students caught up in those deliberations and those issues, then that would have had a personal impact on them.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: In terms of the institution going forward, I'm not aware that they are currently struggling with any disadvantage from that discussion.

oracle_info.speaker: Kirsty Williams AM
oracle_info.content: Well, look, as it's turned out, we have a strong institution in Cardiff Met, and I think, rather than looking at the past, we need to look at the future.

specific_query_list.query: Summarize their discussions on pay dispute situations.

oracle_info.speaker: Dawn Bowden AM
oracle_info.content: When we've seen the teachers' pay settlement, we've seen FE settlements in England and Scotland higher than what's on the table here.

oracle_info.speaker: Dawn Bowden AM
oracle_info.content: It's really: what more do you think you can do as a Government to try to get these parties back round the table and not allow the dispute to become a political football?

oracle_info.speaker: Eluned Morgan AM
oracle_info.content: I think, first of all, you're absolutely right—this is about ColegauCymru's negotiation, but we are keeping a close eye on the situation.

oracle_info.speaker: Eluned Morgan AM
oracle_info.content: I think it's fair to say that we'll wait until they get further along down the line, but we are extremely aware of the sensitivities of the situation.

oracle_info.speaker: Eluned Morgan AM
oracle_info.content: Well, we are listening and speaking to ColegauCymru, and also we're aware of what the unions are saying as well.

oracle_info.speaker: Eluned Morgan AM
oracle_info.content: In relation to teaching, I think it's fair to say that we would wish to see pay equality in relation to teaching, yes.

oracle_info.speaker: Eluned Morgan AM
oracle_info.content: Well, let's see—that's up to ColegauCymru to negotiate and to discuss, so let's see what the outcomes are.

oracle_info.speaker: Eluned Morgan AM
oracle_info.content: Let's wait for the outcome of the negotiations.

oracle_info.speaker: Eluned Morgan AM
oracle_info.content: I think we are very aware of the situation.

oracle_info.speaker: Eluned Morgan AM
oracle_info.content: We're aware of what the requests are from the trade union members, and we'll wait to see what they come up with before responding formally.

oracle_info.speaker: Eluned Morgan AM
oracle_info.content: Well, let's see—that's up to ColegauCymru to negotiate and to discuss, so let's see what the outcomes are.

oracle_info.speaker: Eluned Morgan AM

oracle_info.speaker: Eluned Morgan AM
oracle_info.content: Well, we are listening and speaking to ColegauCymru, and also we're aware of what the unions are saying as well.

oracle_info.speaker: Eluned Morgan AM
oracle_info.content: When they come to a conclusion, and when they come to us and say, 'Look, this is the consequence and this will finish'—at this point, we have no idea where that settlement is likely to fall.

specific_query_list.query: How did Eluned Morgan respond to whether wishing to see people have greater pay equality between schoolteachers and FE when discussing the pay dispute situation?

oracle_info.speaker: Eluned Morgan AM
oracle_info.content: In relation to teaching, I think it's fair to say that we would wish to see pay equality in relation to teaching, yes.

oracle_info.speaker: Llyr Gruffydd AM
oracle_info.content: You emphasise 'in relation to teaching'—my next question is that, of course, within FE establishments you have teaching staff and non-teaching staff, and if there was to be some sort of increase, then would you not expect all staff to have that?

oracle_info.speaker: Eluned Morgan AM
oracle_info.content: Well, let's see—that's up to ColegauCymru to negotiate and to discuss, so let's see what the outcomes are.

oracle_info.speaker: Eluned Morgan AM
oracle_info.content: Let's wait for the outcome of the negotiations.
